149190730.review:
[h2]Zup Series: Achievements for Steam Design Enthusiasts with a Caveat[/h2]

The Zup series, including "Zup! 1-9," "F," "Q," "S," "X," "XS," "Zero," "Zero2," and "qop1-4," is undoubtedly a haven for achievement hunters and Steam profile designers. Each game in the series offers an assortment of colorful letters that can be used creatively to enhance your Steam profile, provided you're willing to put in the effort.

But here's the catch – some might not appreciate the fact that these achievements, when left uncompleted, can significantly lower your overall achievement completion average. To maintain your average, you'll need to meticulously play through every single level of every game, which can amount to hundreds or even thousands of achievements left untouched across the series.

In terms of gameplay, the Zup series starts off relatively easy, but there's a twist. Some levels are better suited for touch screens to nail the timing precisely. And let's not forget about the hidden achievements that require you to tap random parts of the screen on random levels. If you're aiming for that coveted 100%, be prepared to have YouTube at the ready and be ready to spend hours on end working your way through these games.

In summary, the Zup series is a unique achievement treasure for Steam design enthusiasts, but it comes with the caveat of potentially affecting your overall achievement completion average. The gameplay starts easy but can get tricky, especially when touch screens are involved. Hidden achievements add to the challenge, making full completion a test of patience and determination. If you're up for the task, dive in and design your Steam profile with a colorful array of achievements!

Disclaimer: I DO utilize AI to assist in crafting my reviews. Here's how it works:
1. Command: "Help me write a review for (game)"
2. Recommendation: I specify whether I do or don't recommend the title.
3. Tone: I choose a tone for the review (Funny, Professional, Serious, Tired of the Same Crap).
4. Content: I provide known information about the game for inclusion.
5. Optional: Sometimes, I throw in extra flair with commands like "Add Emojis!", "Go Over the Top!", or "Be Colorful!"

By using AI, I aim to bring you reviews that are both insightful and engaging. Thank you for understanding!

106457685.review:
Zup! 3 is a minimal physical puzzle with explosions.

Forgive me for using such foul words.

Yes, I like to 100% games and watch achievements pop up.
But I don’t enjoy watching a meaningless number ramp up, I need to enjoy the game before I can enjoy the achievements I’ve gained with hardwork.

I consider achievements as “word of the devs”, devs communicate with players indirectly via achievements.
Storyline, Easter eggs and Hardcore achievements all have something to offer.
“Beat the fallen guardian” = “Good job! Now teleport through the dark portal and witness the end!”
“Find all hidden treasures” = “Nice observation, how about a hearty handshake?”
“Win the Civil War scenario playing a the Confederates” = “I missed that day in history class XD”
“Beat the game without dying or loading from a savefile” = “You truly mastered the game, grats!”

Besides repeating the same thing over and over 7 times, it’s so sad to make easy money by selling achievements.
But that’s only a glimpse of the sadness iceberg, what’s truly sad are those achievement who support ZUP with all their heart.

I don’t refuse games with tons of achievements. On the contrary, Isaac & Gemcraft are my favorite games, and they have 758 achievements combined. While Isaac can easily offer 200 hours of enjoyment, ZUP gets repetitive after a cup of tea. Without enough content and gameplay to support the achievements, they are dumb and meaningless.

Had to idle the game for 5 minutes in order to write a review, I wish I'd never gain a single achievement from this crap, but 14 achievements popped up upon opening the game. Hope I can warn others with my words.

I know some achievement hunters bought ZUP just because of peer pressure: lots of friends gained 2000 achievements from the series, and I have none.
Well, it’s okay. Nobody will think less of you, just because you didn’t buy ZUP.

If you loathe ZUP just as I do, instead of joining the lemon party and dance towards the seductive booty of braindead achievements, it’s better to give ZUP 4 a negative vote on greenlight and let it never be released.

-2 dientes de ajo
-1 zanahoria
-1 lata de puré de tomates o 3 tomates triturados
-Laurel, pimentón, orégano, tomillo
-Sal
-Pimienta
-Aceite de oliva
-Agua o caldo, cantidad necesaria

-----PASOS-----
Como hacer guiso de arroz tradicional:

-1 Cortar las verduras bien pequeñas, la carne en cubos y desgrasar el chorizo (puede ser hirviéndolo o en una sartén directamente)

-2 En una olla colocar un chorrito de aceite de oliva y sumar los ajos, llevar a fuego y cuando esté bien caliente sumar los cubos de carne. Dorar por todas las caras de la carne.

-3 Sumar las verduras y bajar un poco el fuego, cuando estén transparentes agregar el chorizo en fetas finas y dejar que todo se incorpore bien.

-4 Agregar el puré de tomates, condimentar y agregarle el laurel y las hierbas a gusto. Una vez que la salsa cambie de color (unos minutos después, se pone de un tono más bordó) agregarle 2 tazas de agua. Pueden usar caldo si prefieren, o sumarle un caldito saborizante al agua.

-5 Cuando hierva sumar el arroz y lo cocinamos normalmente. Utilizar el fuego a mínimo así no se pega.

-6 Cocinar hasta que el caldo se consuma casi completamente. En este punto el arroz estará al dente, así que si así es como les gusta ya se retira del fuego. En el caso de que prefieran el arroz bien blandito e integrado a la salsa, agregar un poco más de agua o caldo y cocinar con tapa hasta que tenga el punto deseado.

-7 Una vez cocinado, dejar reposar unos minutos y emplatar. Se puede servir con un poco de ciboulette o perejil esparcido por arriba y un buen pancito para acompañar!

Buen Provecho !

78902765.review:
Zup! 3 is very simplistic and casual friendly, while at the same time it's satisfying to complete. Zup! 3 offers similar gameplay to its' predecessors, offering tons of different achievement icons to unlock to pimp out your Steam Profile.

If you have never played the first two games, here's what you can expect from Zup! 3 and the previous Zup! games.
Your goal is very simple, get the blue ball to land on the green platform without any other blocks or obstacles underneath it. You can move the blue ball by clicking on a red cube, which will cause an explosion and move the blue ball accordingly. Complete all the levels to beat the game and gg. Expect anywhere from twenty minutes to an hour of game-play from this game. Almost all of the achievements are unlocked via simply playing through the game, however there are a few that require you to click on random things in the multiple menu's, on certain levels and things of that nature. Nevertheless, all achievements are very easy to unlock.

6.5/10- There weren't too many changes from the first two games, to this one. While having tons more achievements, the game doesn't offer more levels or game-play than the others. Therefore, I don't find a need to change anything about the games original rating. So long as you're aware you're purchasing a game that was seemingly designed to make your Steam Profile look nice, you'll be satisfied with your purchase.

72650506.review:
[b]Zup! 3[/b] is exactly like its predecessors, in which you click explosive red blocks to guide a blue ball to stop on a green platform, unlocking the exit. The primary reason these are so popular isn't really the gameplay, it's the mess of profile-decorating achievements that come with them, and/or the wallpapers that might drop when you craft their badges. Since [i]Zup 3[/i] is extremely similar to the first and second, this summary will repeat many of the highlights:

[h3]Pros[/h3]
✅ Tiny download, runs on a potato PC just fine
✅ Clean presentation, simple one-click control
✅ 77 levels with 11 optional free DLC
✅ Reliable physics, repeatable each time
✅ The previously DLC-only silver block now makes its way into the main game, adding variety
✅ More clever level design, actual challenge
✅ A few "hidden" achievements for clicking special shapes and background symbols

[h3]Cons[/h3]
❌ No new mechanics
❌ While it has more stages, it's still too short, and should have been combined with the prior games rather than being a standalone entry
❌ Very little replay value
❌ Achievement spam. You'll have to sift through 1700 if you choose to put them on your profile, which is a real chore.
❌ The music is extremely quiet for some reason, with no volume control?

In all likelihood, you are already a target customer for these games if you're reading this: For achievement collectors or profile decorators. Buy it for more of the same, but if you do, try to get it in the series bundle on sale. For everyone else, it's an okay casual puzzle game, but not the best Steam has to offer.

[u]Achievement Hunters[/u]: Complete every stage. Click on every astrological symbol, and group of red blocks that form shapes or symbols (heart, "no" sign, semicolon, etc). The DLC contains no achievements. ~1hr to 100%

60270979.review:
All the games in the zup series are the exact same thing with different levels so what I say in this review is valid of all of them. Currently there are 15 zup games, any future ones will most likely hold this same criticism, however, I can only speak for the current ones.

Zup exists for one thing and one thing only. To pad your achievements on steam. Every level you play gives you a bunch of achievements, even just opening the game for the first time will drown you in achievements. One of the most common reasons for wanting said achievements is for your achievement showcase on your steam profile as each achievement in the game is a letter of the alphabet or a number this game will allow you to spell stuff out in there. If this is all you're looking for out of the game then I suppose it's for you.

Gameplay wise zup sucks. It's a physics based puzzle game with inconsistent physics and easy to solve puzzles (when the physics work). Each zup game is a clone of the others and really should just be sold as one large game since they are identical in everything except the achievements you get and the layout of levels. If they were all combined into one and even had a level editor so users could then create their own levels on the workshop then this game would be worth picking up and even worth more than the $0.99 asking price. But as it is I highly recommended against the game for anything gameplay related. If you're after the achievements and that alone then feel free to pick it up.

I do enjoy the increasing complexity of each level, the incredibly wide set of achievements there are to acquire, and the bold simplicity of the game dynamic itself—click, explode, and hope that the ball lands in the right location in order to progress to the next level. Do you really have to read this review before consider buying this game? Well, you really don't. But why would I waste my time writing this and recommending it to you?!
Are you a 30+ single 9gagger that has a minimum wage job with an overdue assignment, or a teenage kid waiting to graduate from school while your g/b-friend is sleeping with someone else? Do you have a few dollars in your pocket that you're going to spend on depression and low self-esteem while wondering what you have achieved so far in your life? Good news buddy, this is the game for you.
With over hundreds of achievements, you'll feel as rewarding as waking up before the alarm by the time you've finished the game. You may think it's not challenging, but it's actually harder than it looks. You may think it has no moral and it teaches you nothing. Well one thing I've learned: "if at first you don't succeed, try, try, try again. - William Hickson".
It is possible for OCD players like me to have 100% achievement, and [url=store.steampowered.com/developer/zup]Quiet River[/url] has made a bunch of these zups (like Blackberry, Iphone and Windows, they don't have zup9), so you can tell your friends that you have at least achieved something in life.
I'll be lazy and post the same review for the other zups, enjoy the game.

43079025.review:
[b]Zup! 3[/b] is another enjoyable minimalist puzzle, which utilizes simple block physics and challenges you to place a ball within a predetermined winning place. Zup!3 improves on the already successful recipe of its predecessors, with more fun and logic based puzzles, where planning and good timing solves levels, rather than luck. If I had one criticism, I'd say Zup!3 has way too many "trash" achievements, which detract from the overall value of the game. Recommended to everyone.

-----
+ Level difficulty ramps up as you progress
+ Levels are very well-designed; more than a few have that "wow" factor
+ Very enjoyable progression, egging you to keep playing "just one more level"
+ Hidden achievements within levels already completed motivating you to replay them
+ Steam achievements and trade cards

- Trash achievements galore (1708 at the writing of this review)
- Classified as "spam game" from popular ranking sites
- Crashes when exiting, leaving a background instance running (requires manual termination)
- About 1hrs worth of playtime but due to the above bug, overall player times are skewed upwards

This game is essentially shovelware for achievement hunters.

The game presents itself as a puzzle game but there is little intellectual challenge and it takes about 3 attempts per level comprised of trial and error. None of the in game puzzles require any intuition it simply requires experimenting inside a very rudimentary physics engine.

It may seem a bit cheap but I'm simply going to copy and paste the same review for all of these achievement spam games, I apologise in advance to anyone on my friends list checking activity feed :)

All of these games work pretty much the same, you do some very basic things like clicking, leaving the game running, turning left or right, or solving very simple flash mini games to get stupid amount of achievements and more often than not very easy 100% perfect games to add to your profile, which if we can be honest is the only reason people buy these games :) 

You can gain hundred of thousands (literally) achievements in probably less than a day just working your way through these basic "games". Recommended only for those that care about boosting achievement numbers or simply getting easy 100% perfect games.

38396708.review:
Zup! 1 was OK and kinda fresh, Zup! 2 was better with its circular agent, but Zup! 3 gets old and boring fast, with nothing new but (-sorry-) idiotically duplicated achievements; for one level there is a dozen of earned "achievements", half of them being granted for opening the level, half of them for passing it; they all bear the letter or character of the level as name, with only different colors. That's it; no achievement for special feat, for "more-efficient-than-average" success, nothing.

I understand why the Zup! series has over-the-top ratings; it's difficult to "not recommend" these games as they provide some relaxing time and players don't expect much for so little money.
But don't be fooled by Steam's binary rating, Zup! games aren't great puzzle games either; they are based on a simple but effective idea, and provide none to mild puzzle challenge. – The "no challenge" part is much more prevalent than one would expect; many levels are litterally just a display of physics chain reaction in this minimal setting without deduction neither meaningful choice involved. Often there are a bunch of explosive blocks to destroy at once by clicking on one of them, and only one triggers the effect that will make the ball land on the green surface; there is no way to deduce which is the right one, you just empirically try one block after the other.

Zup! is a physics sandbox for the the developer to design levels. I'm pretty sure he has more fun designing them than the players playing them, then selling them for a couple of bucks. You should include the level editor and let the community publish their own levels, and then your Zup! game concept, which is a commendable idea, will reach its full potential.

35538195.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Zup 3 is the third installment of the Zup franchise by Quiet River. With it's simple and easy-to-understand objective, it gets addictive quickly as the game requires you to use your brain with more complex layouts for the ball to land on the designated area.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The visuals are a bit meh...Don't get me wrong. Just because a game has great (and/or realistic) graphics, doesn't mean it's a great game to play in terms of gameplay and replayablity. But the game looks like a flash game. Not to say that's a bad thing, it's just...meh... The background looks pretty plain as well with some random white shapes and a green door to advance the next stage once you've completed a puzzle. Overall, visuals not bad but some may not find it appealing to look at.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game has a very simple objective. You click the red blocks to make force for the yellow blocks which makes the white ball move to the area that will clear the stage. Very simple. But as you advance to the higher stages, you'll need to be quicker mentally to get the timing right. It's easy to understand but can get challenging to master.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
There's none. I'm not joking. As far as I'm aware, there's no offficial soundtrack in the game. For those who play music for the soundtrack, there is none, so you're better off listen to your own music.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's a game that I reccommend for those who are into puzzles and those who are good into speed puzzles. Plus, it comes with nice achievements and Steam trading cards to spice up your profile, if you want to become a fancy and stylish player on Steam. Otherwise if you're not into puzzles, this isn't a reccommendation.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+Addictive gameplay that requires you to use your brain to think and do quick reactions.
+Easy to understand objective.
+Nice achievements and Steam trading cards for your profile.
+Nice colours to look at.
+Becomes challenging later on.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
-Somewhat bland visuals.
-No music whatsoever besides sound effects.
-Not for those that aren't into puzzle games.
-No story.
-All of the above (especially the second dotpoint) can get you to be bored.

[h1]Rating[/h1]
7/10

33187309.review:
So this review is going to be for all Zup! games, not just this one. Therefore, I will be literally copy/pasting this across all of my reviews.
Many people call these games out, citing that they're card farming games. While this may or may not be true, these games have some very good puzzles. Sure, they're short, but I feel that the price I paid for them is well worth it (Less than a dollar for each game in the summer sale?!). Some of the puzzles are really well thought out and it feels good to complete a game like this. So here's the pros and cons.

Pros:
-Good music, never found myself reaching for the mute button. The music IS on a loop, but it's comparable to Hexcells' music, so if you enjoyed that game's music, you'll enjoy their music as well.
-Well designed puzzles, especially in 4 and Zero.

Could be a pro or a con:
-A ton of achievements. If you don't want to artificially inflate your achievement count, don't play any of these passed 1 and 2. If you don't care or you in fact do want to do that, go ahead and play all of them
-Feels like one of those games you would love to play on Flash sites like Newgrounds or Kongregate

Cons: 
-Short, but enjoyable. You could actually fuck the dev(s?) out of money by getting 100% achievements in less than the 2 hour refund period

Overall, I enjoyed these games enough to recommend them all.

This is the 3rd game of the Zup! series. It is popular among achievement hunters due to the sheer number of achievements and fairly easy to obtain all of them.

At the time of this review, I have already played the 1st 2 games of this series. By far, this game is a little bit harder than the previous 2 but it is still possible to obtain all of the 1,708 achievements within 2 hours. This is a puzzle game which provides a fair bit of challenge at the latter levels. As usual, the developers have made a great effort in releasing a bug-free game (a rarity among modern games) and all the achievements are working and in order as the previous 2 games. The physics of this game is superb by the way.

I highly recommend this game to the hardcore achievement hunters as well as for casual gamers. This game is also highly suitable for young children.

31470860.review:
[h1] Чу~ [/h1]

Итак, краткость - сестра таланта, поэтому это будет один из самых моих коротких обзоров. Общая мысль такова: это просто не мой жанр игр. В игре не было багов или каких-то откровенных глупостей, не было пошлости или жестокости, но не было и особого смысла. Слава Богу, что ее можно пройти всего за час (+2 часа на карточки, как вы можете видеть по времени, что я провела в игре), иначе я бы сошла с ума от скуки. Геймплей жутко однообразный. Взорви блок, заставь мячик двигаться, понаблюдай, как он двигается и останавливается на зеленой платформе, кликни на дверь, перейди на следующий уровень. Вот, вроде бы, и все. Все-таки я ожидала более интересные задачки, а предложенные мне уровни были удивительно легкими.

Игра на один раз или для любителей легких ачивок, ни более, ни менее. Лично мне не интересно тратить время на что-то подобное (то же относится и к кликерам), но и бросать вещи на полпути я тоже не могу, поэтому пришлось пройти все до конца. Стоило ли оно того? Ну, учитывая, что я потратила на всю игру всего 1 час, то жить можно. Однако, я не могу дать положительный отзыв игре, которая мне не доставила ни капельки удовольствия от ее прохождения. Одним словом, жаль, что в Steam нет нейтральной оценки. Окончательный вердикт: ничего особенного. Игра на любителя.  

Я очень надеюсь, что мое мнение никого не обидело. Я не преследовала цели унизить поклонников данных игр или смешать с грязью сам жанр. Просто так сложилось, что мне не нравятся подобные произведения и я не вижу причины это скрывать.


[h1] Chu~ [/h1]

This is going to be one of my shortest reviews. And there is a good reason for this – there is not much to talk about. I cannot say that the game is bad, no, but the good parts of it are not worth a positive review. I wish there was a neutral mark, but, unfortunately, Steam sees everything in blue and red only. 

However, I should also mention that this type of games is just not my genre. I like neither clickers nor short plotless games like this. What is the main idea of Zup? Bring the ball to the green platform. Repeat 50 times. Get 1000+ achievements. I hoped for some kind of challenge, but there is none.

Sorry, this is not what I like in games. I gave it a try but that is it. I do not think I will play any other games of this series. They are too simple, too repetitive, in my humble opinion. It does not mean they are bad! It is just not my cup of soup. For this reason, I just cannot give it a positive review even though there were no bugs or obviously unpleasant moments like violence or nudity. 

I hope fans of this game will understand my point of view and will not be offended.

30244024.review:
Zup! is a tiny puzzle game series where you bomb a ball onto a green floor. Each level is short - some require a prayer to RNGesus, most don't. This is the third game in the series and the best of the bunch. It's RNG heavier than the other parts, but it's the only part where Zup! feels like a challenge.

So it's the only Zup! I can really recommend. You get a decent amount of good puzzles and a lot of brainfuck RNG levels, all in a bag filled with 1708 (!) achievements. If you want more achievements but a game that feels extremely tedious, buy Zup! 5.

For comparison, here are the 6 Zup! games so far and how long it took me to get 100%:

Zup! 1: 118 achievements, 17 minutes
Zup! 2: 229 achievements, 26 minutes
Zup! 3: 1708 achievements, 48 minutes
Zup! 4: 555 achievements, 23 minutes
Zup Zero: 1043 achievements, 37 minutes
Zup! 5: 2130 achievements, 46 minutes

¿Por qué, o mejor dicho, para quién es recomendable esta saga de juegos (compuesto por 4 títulos)?

Estamos ante una serie de juegos que comunmente se conocen como "mierdijuegos" o "chorrijuegos". Una interfaz simple y poco trabajada, unos puzzles sencillos y poco desafiantes, el juego se completa en menos de media hora, aburrido ya que apenas supone algún reto, etc.

Pero aún así, lo recomiendo. ¿Por qué? Es un juego, en primer lugar, económico. No vale más de 1 euro, y en oferta lo puedes encontrar por 0,5€ facilmente. Pero existe un gran reclamo que tiene esta saga y es por eso por lo que la gente, como yo, se compra estos juegos: los LOGROS. Hay cientes, pero cientos de logros. A las personas que le gustan conseguir logros y sientan una especie de 0rgasmo o sentimiento de felicidad cuando salta uno, disfrutará enormente cuando vea que en este juego no pararán de aparecer más y más logros desbloqueados.

En definitiva, comprate el juego sí o sí, si te fascinan los logros y aumentar el porcentaje de logros y juegos completados en Steam.

Zup! 3 adds in a few extra elements over Zup! 2
- blocks that can be removed
- levels that require more timing
- some hidden "collectables"

My main issue, and the reason for the downvote, is that this game became entirely about the achievements.
There is absolutely no real feeling behind them - you get something like 9 achievements just for clicking somewhere.

It honestly feels like what I imagine the American education system is like:
- show up at school...get a pass mark immediately!
- spell your name right...you're on the honour roll!
- manage to make it through a whole year without crapping your pants...congrats, you're accepted at every university!

These achievements will make you feel cheap and nasty, like catfishing someone on Tinder into a date...utterly meaningless.

29468625.review:
Zup! 3 is everything that you'll find in the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/JacquesLeSauve/recommended/562220/]previous game[/url] but this time with the added novelty of having almost two-thousand achievements to unlock - easy ones, too, the kind you'll get mostly just by playing the game. I think the justification for this is that they can be used for display on players' profile pages.

So, for example, when you complete the A stage you'll be awarded several "A" achievements of various colours so you have a choice when it comes to showcasing naughty words on your page. But I personally think that's all beside the point; it's there to enjoy or ignore as you please. But I think the real issue with Zup! 3 is that Zup! 2 exists... You just can't recapture that same magic by merely repeating the same trick twice.

While the second in the series felt like an evolution of the idea and brought some fun challenge along with it, this really feels like more of the same without adding much new (not massively surprising given the quick turnaround of all three games). In fact, many stages feel like rethreads of levels from the last game. At one point near the end it threatens to get exciting when it introduces two balls to deal with instead of one. But this is quickly abandoned after a few levels before reverting to type.

Again, as with the previous entries, this is a solid, enjoyable game, and it even lasts longer than the others, too, clocking in at maybe thirty to forty minutes this time. But I can't help but feel a little disappointed that it's merely an extension of the old without ringing in the new. In the event a fourth game is ever released, I hope they just go wild and throw everything at us. Then we'll have something to get excited about.

Yes, I like to 100% games and watch achievements pop up.
But I don’t enjoy watching a meaningless number ramp up, I need to enjoy the game before I can enjoy the achievements I’ve gained with hardwork.

I consider achievements as “word of the devs”, devs communicate with players indirectly via achievements.
Storyline, Easter eggs and Hardcore achievements all have something to offer. 
“Beat the fallen guardian” = “Good job! Now teleport through the dark portal and witness the end!”

“A!” = “You want more achievements? Vote for me on greenlight!”
“A!” = “You want more achievements? Vote for me on greenlight!”

“A!” = “You want more achievements? Vote for me on greenlight!”
“A!” = “You want more achievements? Vote for me on greenlight!”
…….
Besides repeating the same thing over and over 7 times, it’s so sad to make easy money by selling achievements.
But that’s only a glimpse of the sadness iceberg, what’s truly sad are those achievement whores who support ZUP with all their heart.

I don’t refuse games with tons of achievements. On the contrary, Isaac & Gemcraft are my favorite games, and they have 758 achievements combined. While Isaac can easily offer 200 hours of enjoyment, ZUP gets repetitive after a cup of tea. Without enough content and gameplay to support the achievements, they are dumb and meaningless. 

Had to idle the game for 5 minutes in order to write a review, I wish I'd never gain a single achievement from this crap, but 14 achievements popped up upon opening the game. Hope I can warn others with my words.

I know some achievement hunters bought ZUP just because of peer pressure: lots of friends gained 2000 achievements from the series, and I have none.
Well, it’s okay. Nobody will think less of you, just because you didn’t buy ZUP.

If you loathe ZUP just as I do, instead of joining the lemon party and dance towards the seductive booty of braindead achievements, it’s better to give ZUP 4 a negative vote on greenlight and let it never be released.

29330993.review:
This is what I had to say about the first Zup!:

"To be enirely honest, I went into this with very low expectations. This was mostly due to my prior experiences with Super Duper Flying Genocide 2017, another recent title that markets itself in a similar fashion. "Short, Simple, Earn loads of achievements". And I'd be lying if I said this game is perfect, but I have to give praise where praise is due. This game really surprised me!

The very first distinction I'd like to make between this and Super Duper Flying Genocide 2017 is that unlike that dissappointment, I would actually consider this a game and a rather enjoyable and intuitive one at that! It is clear that Zup! goes for the same demographic; achievement hunters, completionists, whatever you want to call them. I consider myself part of that group, so I felt inclined to give this game a try despite my rather low expectations. Very much like the building blocks that you interact with in Zup! my expectations were blown away! This is definitely a puzzle game first and foremost, and an achievement treasure second.

Your objective is to bring the blue square onto the green tiles through the use of explosions. The red squares are explosive and clicking them will make them blow up, knocking any yellow and blue squares away in the process. It really is as simple as that. But just because the mechanics are simple it doesn't necessarely mean that the game itself is easy, in fact I'd say far from it.

The levels start out easy enough, and for the first few levels it feels like this might have actually been a bad choice after all, just another cash grab copy paste job with loads of achievements attached, but then you reach level 10 and things start to get interesting. As you progress through the game each level becomes more and more challenging and you need to both think of the right solution and make use of your reflexes and predictions to launch the blue square with the right trajectory and force to get it where it needs to be.

Soon I had forgotten about my prior pessimism and was instead joyfully exploring in how many ways I could try to knock the yellow block-towers down and with what sort of speed I could send the blue square flying in order to solve the puzzle in front of me. The simple yet addictive nature of the game had caught me entirely off guard and I was getting more and more intrigued and hopeful for the next challenge the game would provide me with...

And then it ended. Just like that.

If anything, that would be my only real gripe with the title, it is extremely short. I beat the whole thing with 100% achivements in only a couple of minutes, and I wish it would go on for a bit longer as I was actually having quite a bit of fun with it. But to be fair the game has a very low price point and the tags do describe it as "short" so I should have been expecting it to end rather quickly.

All that said, I hope you understand my thoughts about this game but in case I was too lengthy in my description of it and the enjoyment it gave me let me try to sum it up in a few short words:

This is a short but fun and intuitive physics puzzle game. I had a lot of fun with it and the achievements are a bonus rather than the main focus. I recommend this highly if you want some quick fun, and I suggest you pick up the Zup-Zup! Bundle which hosts all three games for a very affordable price. I have not yet played the other two titles, but if they are anywhere as good as this then I cannot recommend it enough."

After playing the two sequels I can happily say that they are worthy successors. If you liked the first two games, you are going to like this. If you did not, you won't find anything different here. It's the same concept with more levels, more achievements and more Zup!

One thing this one tries to innovate with is the introduction of white blocks that you can remove by clicking on them. These give further depth and variation to the levels, but unfortunately come with the downside of making things feel a bit more trial and error. Some levels can feature ten+ white blocks in a row, and the smallest variation in which blocks are removed can completely change the outcome of the level. I felt the will to innovate was welcome, but sadly I believe this to be the least enjoyable of the three games as the white blocks took away from the game's simplistic but challenging and fair nature, and put it closer to the concept of "repeat until you succeed".

None the less, this is still a very nice simplistic puzzle game for a very affordable price. I recommend you check out the first two, and if you like them, then come back and play this afterwards.

29292923.review:
108 minutes played. In that time, I obtained more than 1700 achievements. We're through the looking glass here, folks.

As much as I enjoyed [i]Zup![/i] and [i]Zup! 2[/i] (a deceptively-simple pair of puzzle games that have you clicking on explosive red blocks in order to get a blue block over to a green platform and unlock the next stage), this third installment is already pushing the limits of what I'm willing to tolerate. I considered the DLC for the second game a neat little bonus, but it's as if the developers saw how much people were playing their little title and decided to go all post-modern and edgy on their player base.

You can't start this game for the first time without getting 20 achievements. Click on anything on the screen, another 3-6 achievements. There are so many achievement messages coming on-screen at once that it actually messes with the flow of the game in certain situations, by making it so that you either have to wait or click through the achievements in order to activate the exit gate.

And that's not even getting into the game itself, whose sole innovation this time is that the item you have to get into the green "safe" area is now a ball instead of a square, and there are white tiles you have to click on in later levels in order to make them vanish and solve certain puzzles. Couldn't this have just been produced as an add-on for the previous title?

I'm not sure who this game was intended for. The achievement symbols themselves are noticeably less polished and refined than the ones from the original game (which look very nice in an achievement showcase, similar to how [i]LYNE[/i] had its set of achievements). There's no real innovation or unique designs on display here other than a reliance in the later levels of using "step" tiles to roll the ball into certain areas. The achievements feel like a giant joke that was designed to undermine and trivialize Steam's achievement system.

You're better off sticking with the first two games and not wasting your time on this unless you're desperate for more achievements. Even then, the sheer absurdity of the way achievements are integrated with the game is off-putting.

An incredibly easy [i]puzzle[/i] game that has nothing unique going for it other than an idiotic amount of spam achievements.

The objective of the game is to move the ball from point A to point B, sounds simple enough, and it is and if you take a quick glance at the screenshots on the store page having never played any other of the Zup games it might look like the difficulty gets higher and higher, but it doesn't.

The achievement system is undoubtly put in the game by the developer to bait people who want 1.7K achievements to buy it, and it's worked.
It's the same thing the asset flip games do except with trading cards; game costs a few cents on the store making it so the buyer[i](and in turn the game developer)[/i] profits from the trading cards.
This is how the game sells, people buy it because they can make their money back from the trading cards.

And with this game, people only buy it so they can get an idiotic amount of achievements to show on their Steam profile.

I really hope Valve does something about this.

All-in-all, a very simple and easy puzzle game where you move a ball from point A to point B.
It's a sorta game you'd expect to find on a free flash game website.
Rather it's been released on Steam and the developer is doing something scummy to be able to sell their bad game.

29215136.review:
The third instalment of the Zup! franchise takes what is loved about the previous two games, and turns it up to 11, or 1708 in the case of the number of achievements. Nothing noteworthy has been added; the overall difficulty is slightly increased, and in a few of the later levels there are two blue blocks instead of one, but the gameplay is essentially unchanged.

The main attraction is once again the achievements, with over seven times the amount found in Zup! 2. Each level gives at least 14 (seven from opening, and another seven for beating it), and there are a few hidden ones along the way. Some levels require somewhat precise timing to clear, but the game can still be completed in under an hour. There is also no reason to replay a level unless you want to figure out an alternative way of clearing.

The game can probably stand on its own merits, but is clearly targeted at achievement hunters. Concerns about devaluing achievements aside, this has started a trend of cheap games with a massive number of achievements to make a sale. I'm unsure what kind of problems this will lead to in the near future.

Ultimately, Zup! 3 is at least still a game, and should still be worth a look if you know what the game is about.

29210822.review:
[h1]1708 Achievements in One Hour![/h1]

Zup! 3, the newest installment in the minimalistic puzzle series was just released with 1708 achievements. With such an insane boost to any collector’s count, and at such a low cost, this game is pretty much an insta-buy. I can probably guarantee that 80% of the people checking the reviews right now are just wondering how easy and how long it will take to get them all. The answer is: super easy, and most likely under an hour (upwards to 2 hours depending on skill). 

[h1]Those Missing Achievements[/h1]

In fact, the achievements are so easy to get, there are probably only a handful of moments where there wasn’t an achievement getting unlocked. With 77 levels to play through, the achievement requirements basically include: opening/beating all levels, clicking anywhere, restarting levels, and finding specific symbols/shapes “hidden” (in plain sight) throughout the levels. The Discussions are starting to get flooded with questions of missing achievements. 

Hint: some of the symbols are obvious, some will require some "needless" exploding.
Hint 2: take another look around levels: F, L, S, 2, <, [.

[h1]What About the Game?[/h1]

Regarding the gameplay, I’ve actually found it to be somewhat enjoyable, much more than other cheap cash grabs on Steam, but something expected for a single dollar title. This physics based puzzle game revolves around clicking explosion blocks to propel hardened blocks/ball(s) to a goal platform. The physics is oddly satisfying, since there is an order to the madness. Blocks will magically land in such a way (skewed, angled, stacked, blocked, etc.) to get the ball to the goal. Most of the levels do require a little bit of timing, so it isn't just a monotonous slog, but there isn’t anything real challenging here. There are definitely a few cheeky levels thrown in there for the dev to have some fun too.

29208719.review:
Chances are you already know Zup! as the achievement whoring puzzler with copious amounts of achievements to get.

This is the same game, different day. There are a few new additions such as dual balls or click-to-break blocks which give the game a new challenge. It's a fun game, but you won't feel good about completing it. If you're just here for the road to completionist, or to add thousands of achievements to your profile, grab Zup! 3.

It's under a dollar at retail, it has over 1,700 achievements, that's almost 1,500 more than Zup! 2. The game can be completed in anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour, depending on how familiar you are with the Zup! series.

It's an alright game, if you're here for achievements, don't let me stop you. I just wish that with 1,700 achievements, there would be more levels and a higher challenge. The game is clearly too easy even to "master" at 100%. There were some levels that made you think and took some time to get the timing right. The final level was WAY too simple. Either way, it's a bearable 100%, and who's going to say no to 1,700 achievements in 30 minutes?
